group.title: Communicating Passwords
group.instructions: The password policy may tell users whether or not they can provide their passwords to other people, under particular circumstances.

group.title: To Other People
group.instructions: The policy may address whether passwords can be communicated to other people.

page.title: Communication to Other People
page.instructions: The policy may address whether passwords can be communicated to other people.

group.title: Using these Methods
group.instructions: The policy may address specific methods for communicating passwords (e.g., mail, email, Internet, phone, etc.).

group.title: Using the Internet or a Wide Area Network (WAN)
Creating Passwords
group.instructions:
You will be asked about what characters, words, or pre-existing passwords can be used in passwords.

The following questions about characters address:

  • password length (minimum and maximum);
  • the types of characters used in passwords;
  • the positions within passwords where certain characters can be used; and
  • combinations, sequences, and patterns of characters.
]]>

group.title: Length
group.instructions: The policy may address the number of characters that may or may not be used in passwords.

page.title: Minimum and Maximum
page.instructions: The policy may address the number of characters that may or may not be used in passwords.

group.title: Character Types
group.instructions: The following questions address the types of characters and number of those characters types that may or may not be used in passwords.

group.title: Multiple Types of Characters
group.instructions:
The following questions address the types of characters and number of those characters that may or may not be used in passwords. More specifically, the policy may have rules relating character selection criteria that pertain to a combination of two or more types of characters.

Example: Passwords should be composed of letters and numbers.

This type of rule focuses on a combination of character types and is handled in this section.

group.title: Character Positions: First, Last, etc.
group.instructions:
The policy may address the use of specific characters

  • as the first or last character of a password;
  • in the middle of a password (any position between the first and last characters); or
  • near the beginning of a password (i.e., within the first N characters).

    • The following questions will ask about each of these. ]]>

group.title: First or Last Character
group.instructions: One example of how a policy may state this type of rule is, "Passwords cannot begin or end with punctuation."

group.title: Internal Characters
group.instructions: A policy may include this type of rule this way, "Passwords must include special characters, but cannot begin or end with them."

group.title: Near the Beginning
group.instructions:
Example: "Passwords must include a number within the first 5 characters."
If a statement specifically refers to the very first character of a password, respond using the "First or Last Character" topic.

page.title: At the Beginning
page.instructions:
Example: "Passwords must include a number within the first 5 characters."
If a statement specifically refers to the very first character of a password, respond using the "First or Last Character" topic.

group.title: Repeating, Recurring, Sequential and Unique Character Use

page.title: Repeating, Recurring, Sequential and Unique Characters

group.title: Incorrect Password Entry
group.text: The policy may describe consequences for entering incorrect passwords during login attempts.

page.title: Incorrect Entry
page.text: The policy may describe consequences for entering incorrect passwords during login attempts.

group.title: Lockout Duration and Recovery
group.text: The policy may describe additional consequences for entering incorrect passwords during login attempts.

page.title: Lockout and Recovery
page.text: The policy may describe additional consequences for entering incorrect passwords during login attempts.

Rule example 2: Passwords must include both letters and numbers. (Two rules, each about a single type of character.)

question.title: Characters <u>should</u> come from a specific character type
question.text: Does the policy recommend that password characters should come from a specific character type?
question.instructions:
The following questions address the types of characters and number of those characters of one particular type that should be used in passwords. More specifically, the policy may have rules relating character selection criteria that pertain to a single type of character.

Example: Passwords should include both letters and numbers. In this example, two rules are given, but each focuses on a single character type: 1) it recommended that passwords contain letters and 2) it is recommended that passwords contain numbers. This rule type is addressed in this section.

However, if the rule had been stated as: Passwords should be composed of letters and numbers, this is one rule that focuses on a combination of character types and is handled in the next section - Multiple Types of Characters.

option.text: No
Yes

question.title: Characters must not come from a specific character type
question.text: Does the policy prohibit using characters from a specific character type?
question.instructions:
The following questions address the types of characters and number of those characters of one particular type that must not be used in passwords. More specifically, the policy may have rules relating character selection criteria that pertain to a single type of character.

Example: Passwords must not include punctuation or numbers. In this example, two rules are given, but each focuses on a single character type: 1) passwords are prohibited from containing punctuation and 2) passwords are prohibited from containing numbers. This rule type is addressed in this section.

However, if the rule had been stated as: Passwords must not include both punctuation and numbers, this is one rule that focuses on a combination of character types and is handled in the next section - Multiple Types of Characters.

option.text: No
Yes

The following questions address the types of characters and number of those characters that may or may not be used in passwords. More specifically, the policy may have rules relating character selection criteria that pertain to a combination of two or more types of characters.

Example: Passwords must not be composed of punctuation and numbers.

This type of rule focuses on a combination of character types and is handled in this section - Multiple Types of Characters.

option.text: No
Yes

question.title: Lockout Duration and Recovery
question.text: When a user is locked out after entering incorrect passwords:

option.text: the lockout lasts for an unspecified period of time.

option.text: an administrator must unlock the account.

If you forget this username, your account and any saved responses cannot be recovered. Only a scrambled version is ever stored in order to protect your identity.
This application does not use passwords.

help.html:
Help is provided in the form of potential questions that users may ask. Select a link from the Help Topics on This Page to view that topic. To leave a comment concerning help or to request that someone contact you, please use the General Comment function.

Help Topics on This Page

  • Function of Password Policy Formalization application
  • What is a Policy Statement
  • What is my Role as a User
  • In Scope & Out-of-scope topics
  • Supported Browsers
  • Pop-ups and Java script
  • Required Fields and Questions
  • Reporting Issues, Problems, Observations
  • Your UserID
Function of Password Policy Formalization application
NIST will compile participants' responses and use them to determine how users interpret password policy statements. By analyzing the responses of numerous participants, NIST intends to identify policy statement wording that is clear and unambiguous and ones that are not. NIST intends to use the results to develop a password 'grammar' that organizations could use to write clearer password policies. Further, single and combinations of policy statements can then be isolated and analyzed for usability and security characteristics. The result is to provide policy developers with guidelines to reduce user frustration and confusion and improve compliance while improving system security.
What is Policy Statement
Password policy statements typically refer to directions to users about creating, communicating, storing, and changing passwords; as well the consequences of failing to authenticate. There are typically four types of statements that direct the user how to comply with the policy:
  • What the user "must" do
  • What the user "must not" do
  • What the user "should" do
  • What the user "should not" do
Role as a User
When you use the application, you will choose a real-world password policy from the list of policies. Once a policy is selected for review, you will be asked a series of questions about the rules contained in that policy. You should select the responses that closely reflect your understanding of what the policy states. Some questions may not be applicable to the policy you selected, but an response option should be available to indicate that situation.
In-Scope & Out-of-Scope Topics
In-Scope
The scope for this project is password policy statements that pertain to general, non-privileged accounts. As opposed to policy statements regarding a privileged account such as one that would be a system administrator.

Out-of-Scope
This effort is directed towards password policy statements for general user accounts, i.e., non-privileged accounts. There are a number of topics that are out-of-scope for this effort and questions about these topics are not included in the password policy questions. These topics include:
  • Passphrases and SSH keys
  • Password guidelines for administrators, privileged accounts, and super users
  • Vague statements, such as "Passwords should be memorable", are out of scope in this effort. 
Back to Top
Supported Browsers
The application is platform independent and works with the following browsers:
  • Firefox versions 34 and above
  • Chrome version 39.X and above
Please report any technical issues through the General Comment page.

Note that Internet Explorer and Safari do *not* work with the application. Please avoid their use for this application.
Pop-Ups & Java Script
For the application to function correctly, you will need to enable both pop-ups and Java script in your browser. Directions for enabling pop-ups in your selected browser are below:

    Enabling Pop-ups

    Mozilla Firefox
  1. Select the Menu button (upper right hand corner)
  2. Choose options
  3. Select the Content panel
  4. Block pop-up windows check box by checking the box or uncheck to unblock    
    Chrome
  1. In the top right corner of the browser, click the Chrome menu icon
  2. Select Settings
  3. Click show advanced settings (link at the bottom of the page)
  4. Under "Privacy", click the Content settings button 
  5. Under "Pop-ups", select the Allow all sites to show pop-ups or click Manage exceptions 

Back to top

Required Fields and Questions
You are not required to answer any of the questions - there are no required fields.  However, we request you provide answers to each question presented to you if possible. If you are confused or do not think that the available answers are appropriate, then please let us know in the Optional Comment section at the bottom of the question page. We have also provided a general comment link (located at the top right hand corner of the page) for any feedback, comments, or problems.
Reporting Issues, Comments, Observations
If you see any issues, have any observations of, or comments about a policy or policy questions, please use the comment area below the questions to report these issues, observations, or comments. Additionally, if there are insufficient choices for any question or comment, please let us know!

Please use the General Comment option located at the top right hand corner on any page to enter any comments about the application, other observations, or technical issues.
Your UserId
Please keep your UserId safe. If you forget your userid, we cannot recover it for you. We are only allowed to store a scrambled version to preserve your anonymity and protect your identity. Unfortunately, if you cannot remember your UserId, you will need to create a new one for continued use of the application. Since each policy review is associated with an individual UserId, any previous review effort continues to be assoicated with your former UserId and you will lose access to it. Please keep your UserId safe.
